data.body: I would call it `dithering` instead of `removeBanding`.
Which one in https://www.shadertoy.com/view/MslGR8 is it?

Yeah, I can call it `dithering`. Is there anything else?

Do I need to change anything in the JSON loader or output?

It's the fourth one up from the bottom. I thought it looked the most even and didn't seem too complicated.
@WestLangley Got it. Thanks...
@mrdoob @WestLangley Please check again.
Sweet!
Thanks!

Uhmm... This does indeed remove the banding on the lit parts, but adds a strange pattern to the dark parts...

![screen shot 2017-03-30 at 15 52 11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/97088/24529545/0ca5d280-1561-11e7-9438-bb60cb1a05f2.png)

Oh yeah, I see it. You have to look pretty close. It's a good thing it's optional and off by default for now...

I guess there's no getting around some kind of noise in the darkness, but maybe we can try another option that isn't such a regular pattern. Maybe try the third one from the bottom on that shadertoy link? It doesn't look too complicated. Some of the options vary the noise by time, but I don't think that's a good idea for three.js.
I wonder if it has something to do gamma correction?
That's above my pay grade. But there's gonna be some noise - that's the trade off for hiding the banding. It's just a question of how much does it stand out.
/ping @bhouston
The above-referenced link, http://loopit.dk/banding_in_games.pdf, contains a lot of detail, and is worth studying if anyone is interested in pursuing this further.

@WestLangley Should we swap `<dithering_fragment>` and `<fog_fragment>`?

https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/dev/src/renderers/shaders/ShaderLib/meshphysical_frag.glsl#L77-L81

BTW encoding is a bit tricky because in the implement of that I combined monotonic color space conversions (Linear, Gamma, sRGB) with complex/non-monotonic encodings (RGBM, RGBD, LogLUV and RGBE).  If you use one of the complex/non-monotonic encodings, you are NOT allowed to use fog, premultiplied alpha or dithering, as those have assumptions on RGBA meaning RGBA, rather than an encoded value.

Also we should probably added some CMYK and other neat color conversions to the encoding, that would be useful in the printing space.
And then each texture and render target should have both a ColorSpace (Linear, sRGB, AdobeRGB, Gamma20, Gamma22) and a Encoding (None, RGBE, RGBM, RGBD, LogLUV, CMYK) parameter.

I've reordered the includes as per https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/pull/11076#issuecomment-293567895 but there seems to be artefacts still:

![screen shot 2017-04-15 at 23 25 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/97088/25069319/cfb9f70a-2232-11e7-8c91-daffaa568f3e.png)

It is much better though!

This other example shows the artefacts more clearly:

![screen shot 2017-04-15 at 23 29 34](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/97088/25069346/a23677f8-2233-11e7-9b5a-454b87ea707d.png)

I am a bit confused because do not see obvious artifacts in these two images in the shadow penumbra.  Could you be a bit more clear as to the type of artifacts you are seeing (banding, stripes, etc.) and where exactly are they?  Maybe the artifacts are visible in a before/after scenario and I am missing the before scenario?

Well... That's interesting.... Loaded the screenshot on Gimp and after scaling it up the artefacts disappear. Turns out is something to do with the screen on the MacBook Air?  I don't see the artefacts on other devices. I'll take a couple of photos...

For me (on Windows 10) all sceenshots look absolutely fine in each browser (and also in Photoshop -
 independent of the coosen color space) at each zoom level.

> Turns out is something to do with the screen on the MacBook Air?

Some screens, although I didn't think it would be Apple, do have reduced bitdepth in their LCD displays.  This can lead to banding that isn't actually in the image.

There is this forum post on banding issues with MacBook Air: https://discussions.apple.com/thread/4343229?tstart=0

Also seems to affect Safari in some cases: https://forum.justgetflux.com/topic/213/fullscreen-youtube-colour-artefacting

I think that the MacBook Air has good bit depth in the LCD but there are often software issues.

A couple of random points after skimming through this
- the dithering pattern will, as you have noticed, of course show in dark areas. This is a good argument for using noise rather than a pattern. One of the best ones is blue noise: [http://momentsingraphics.de/?p=127](http://momentsingraphics.de/?p=127)
- whatever pattern you use, it should have a traingular distribution - the "ceejay" one you currently use does not - it should be reshaped and extended to the range [-1;1]. I quickly threw together an example, hopefully not too wrong [https://www.shadertoy.com/view/ldjyDw](https://www.shadertoy.com/view/ldjyDw)
- using a texture is quite likely faster, but if you continue to use a procedural pattern, I would suggest RGB-interleaved gradient noise as it is less noticable.

Hard to see with all the moire...

![img_20170417_085246](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/97088/25096269/5afea0aa-2354-11e7-81c4-e28136e376f6.jpg)

Well, there is definitely something there... I've loaded the [first screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/97088/24529545/0ca5d280-1561-11e7-9438-bb60cb1a05f2.png) on gimp, and played with the curves a bit for the dark values and the diagonal pattern reveals.

![screen shot 2017-04-17 at 10 15 46](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/97088/25096858/e45c66a0-2356-11e7-87cb-8a5934dac9bf.png)

![screen shot 2017-04-17 at 10 12 21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/97088/25096775/9525538a-2356-11e7-8a0c-5e6d7eda4bf6.png)

Colorspaces do complicate everything, and they are indeed different on mac/win (iirc mac is pow2.4 where windows is srgb). I have had the good fortune of not having to deal too much with it, but you might want to have a look at this presentation, attempting a colorspace-independant solution [GdcVdrLottes.pdf](http://32ipi028l5q82yhj72224m8j.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/GdcVdrLottes.pdf) .
